paper.title: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccines sensitize tumours to immune checkpoint blockade

core_question: Does intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy?

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse efficacy cohort (combination therapy)
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 78 tumor-bearing mice pooled across repeat experiments receiving combination therapy of intratumoral mRNA vaccine and anti-PD-L1.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Mouse control cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: 84 tumor-bearing mice pooled across matched controls receiving vaccine only, ICI only, and vehicle treatments.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human retrospective metastatic cohort
datasets_or_cohorts.description: A retrospective cohort of 130 metastatic patients total receiving immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human vaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subgroup of 43 patients who received prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination before ICI treatment.

datasets_or_cohorts.label: Human unvaccinated subgroup
datasets_or_cohorts.description: Subgroup of 87 patients who were unvaccinated for SARS-CoV-2 prior to ICI treatment.

major_limitations: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
Vaccination timing relative to ICI initiation varied across patients.
Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.
Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
